content.webTitle: The Night Manager recap: episode two – welcome to Camp Roper

fields.headline: The Night Manager recap: episode two – welcome to Camp Roper
fields.bodyText: Spoiler alert: this recap assumes you’ve seen episode two of The Night Manager. Don’t read on if you haven’t. God, this show is artfully made. The first episode was explosive and romantic and beautiful to look at, attaching itself like a limpet mine to your hull of a nervous system. The second took a subtler tack. For all its violence, and while it still looked lovely, this week’s instalment was a stowaway, an anxious exercise in accumulation, and the steady, sinister method by which Pine went about insinuating himself into Roper’s affections. Is he there yet? Is Roper seduced by a fellow psychopath or suspicious that he’s a psycho-plant? I don’t know. I don’t suppose he does, either. And I’m certain Pine doesn’t. “There’s half a psychopath in there,” Burr told him, when geeing her new asset up for his transformation; as he set himself to the task of becoming a convincingly remorseless thug, you wondered whether the other half was clicking into place as well. The traumatically handsome Tom Hiddleston If there’s something a bit cliched about the spy as lost soul, hero unmoored from conventional morality by What They Make You Give, Tom Hiddleston’s performance of it is entirely fresh. He’ll make a great Bond some day, if he wants. (Sometimes this feels like an audition piece.) Last week’s public school charmer is much less in evidence this time around, but it’s not that you feel he’s just playing a different part. Instead, as Pine mutes his conscience, it’s as if a teacher’s left the room. It helps that Hiddleston is so traumatically handsome, with the kind of face that’s bound to leave you off balance at the best of times, let alone when he’s winding an extension cord around a small-time Devonian drug dealer’s neck. His manners have been so impeccable up until now that the change feels like a betrayal – and all the more thrilling for that. The chillier his behaviour, the more we identify with him: because his violence has a seductive edge, and because we enjoy it, we feel complicit in the compromise he’s making, and hence fully signed up to the confrontation with Roper that undoubtedly lies ahead, strapped to the same bomb. Mallorca, Devon, Zermatt It’s not just Hiddleston’s performance that puts us off balance: the story drags us from location to location, repeatedly dropping us into situations where we’re not quite sure who’s playing who or for what. In the opening set piece we watch Roper’s girlfriend, Jed, do a lot of languorous showering and lingerie-fiddling, then talking to her mother, who evidently hates her, about someone called Billy, who is presumably her son, and who apparently doesn’t ask about her any more. Her mother says, uncharmingly, that she is “nothing but a dirty whore”; Jed takes a load of pills then heads out to play the perfect surrogate mother to Roper’s son, Danny. Danny is on screen as source of contrast and vulnerability, but he’s also Chekhov’s gun, and from the moment he appears he makes us uneasy, because at some point he’s obviously going to go off. But as Jed danced adorably with him in the seaside restaurant, I wasn’t quite prepared for it to happen so abruptly. And then, just as we think the boy’s going to be disappeared, we see Pine’s glassy eye through a hole in a door; and then we turn on a sixpence and head six months backwards to Zermatt. It’s a disorienting opening, and by the same token utterly compelling. Pine, we learn, is hiding behind that door because the kidnapping is a set-up, a choreographed chance for him to play the hero and ingratiate himself with Roper and his cohorts. His trip to Devon is mandated by Burr, who sends him there to acquire the criminal identity he will need if Roper is ever going to believe in him. (“There’s not a scrap of you that won’t be used,” says Burr, “there’s not an hour that you won’t be scared, but you will nail him.”) Sometimes this sojourn veers into the parodic – there’s a great bit where he showers under a waterfall, and he single-handedly transforms his dilapidated cottage into a backdrop for a Cath Kidston catalogue in no time at all. There’s nothing terribly original about the wide-eyed lass who falls for him, either, although she’s well played by Hannah Steele. (I look forward to television’s first ever west country girl who isn’t pale, dissatisfied and secretly randy for a posh boy.) Still, the chapter serves its purpose, and soon Pine is ready for his trip into the lion’s den – both in terms of his backstory and because of his rapid reacquaintance with the violence that shaped his first career. His insertion into Camp Roper is, honestly, a little ridiculous too. Roper is a supervillain with hyper-paranoid instincts and life-preservingly strong reasons to maintain them. I’m not sure he would entertain the notion that a man he first met as a hotel night manager in Zermatt has coincidentally pitched up as a chef in his favourite Mallorcan restaurant and saved his son from an unrelated kidnapping. In fact, it’s so daft that I wonder whether the eventual payoff will reveal that Roper knew he was a spy all along, and drew him in as part of some as yet unspecified masterplan. Hollander’s sauce Whatever the truth, at least Corcoran, Roper’s suavely menacing righthand man (though everyone in this show is suavely menacing, with the possible exception of Angela Burr and the kid) smells a rat. I think Tom Hollander’s performance here is my favourite thing in The Night Manager. Corcoran has a fantastically specific language, a dead-eyed, sing-song pantomime of politesse that leaves you in no doubt that he would like nothing better than to cut your toes off and stick them up your nose. And Hollander manages the right balance of assurance and resentment without seeming silly: men like Pine, you suspect, weren’t terribly nice to him at school. (So much of this series has made me wonder about the indignities heaped on its protagonists during their well-appointed childhoods.) “I’m not sure we’re quite as poorly as we’re making out,” Corcoran tells our hero, with a menacingly menacing air of menace, as he recuperates under Roper’s roof. “In fact I’m not sure at all about you, Pine. I think you might be stringing us along.” If this turns out to be the case, he carefully explains, “I will hood you and hang you up by those lovely ankles until the truth falls out of you by gravity. Toodleoo.” Roper’s doubts aren’t quite so violent, but he makes them known in his own scarily affable manner. “You sleep now,” he says. “Tomorrow we’ll find out who you really are.” As the episode ends, Pine ponders the weight of that promise, and doesn’t appear to be much looking forward to its fulfilment in the morning. We, for our part, will have to bide our time till next week to see how it goes. I can’t wait. Notes and observations If Pine and Jed don’t end up sleeping together I’ll eat my hat. People that good-looking just don’t orbit each other on television without having sex. Or not for long, anyway. I love the assortment of grey men who make up the British espionage establishment. Surely not even the one played by Neil Morrissey can be as dense as they all seem: when are they going to catch on to what Pine’s doing, and what will the consequences be? There were some nice veiled resonances in Danny’s reading to Pine about underwater life. “Do you want me to read to you about squid?” he asked, and began: “this slow-moving alien-like squid lives at depths …” You might apply that description equally to Roper and Pine alike. We haven’t actually seen Roper do anything mean yet. All of his violence and cruelty is contained, even when his son’s life is under threat. The explosion should be worth the wait. I’d lay a large bet that a screengrab of Tom Hiddleston in his undercrackers will make the Daily Mail tomorrow. Aidan Turner had better look out. Episode one recap
